data.content:
Where to start... well its certainly a mobile type game, why?? its not like the iPhone or iPad is not capable, they have more processing power than previous generation consoles.

Lets start £7.99 ...wait WHAT ....now £9.99!!! …its a mobile game Nintendo and a bad one at that!!

First impressions were just okay, what could I expect from a mobile game, named Super Mario Run ...well, all you do is press the screen to jump, to collect coins and kill enemies.

However the major issues are that you cannot play the game offline, so forget playing Tour mode when theres no data or wifi available! 

Your £7.99 ....wait, now £9.99 is going towards a season type pass?? ...waste of money, as when the servers go offline theres no more Super Mario Run. 

I ended up purchasing the game by getting a £15 iTunes voucher from a well know site for £9 which was great, as I do regret the purchase. Ended up paying £2.00 for the game, which is still overpriced! Last mistake I make in 2017, no Switch for me! =P

I have played all the world and I must admit the first two worlds were good, after that ...the game felt rushed, like they ran out of ideas. The levels just kept getting shorter, less challenging and dull.

When I finished all the worlds I was expecting a nice Mario ending ...well I did worked hard to finish the game like collecting all the coins etc etc ....and what I got was nothing ...it was like heres Peach, Game Over!!! Great!!

The Rally mode is the Vs. mode where you play against over players or do you?? anyways if you like Rally mode you will never be short of tickets to play the game. I have all the special blocks and while I have 99 (which is the max) tickets ...I just get more from the blocks every few hours.

You can also build up your kingdom, it not really my thing …so I will not go into it. But if you do make the mistake and buy the game you will not be short on coins or Rally tickets so you can pretty much buy everything and play what ever you want.

After you complete the game and have x amount of things there will be special levels available which are hard as....is this the challenge I was looking for NO, it stupid like MK8 200cc stupid!

Anyways I really hope Nintendo don't make any more games like this...its a budget game with a now huge corporate price tag. People who don't mind paying this price …all I can say is well since you have deep pockets fell free and send me some of you hard earned cash! =) ..oh, whats that I hear, yeah I though so!!!

data.content:
This is how the whole game should be difficulty wise. It's far too easy to breeze through all the levels. 

The real gaming starts when you collect the coloured coins.. you get rewarded mini-games once complete.

Rally Mode is far more challenging and has potential to be quite fun with friends! They've recently updated it so that Toads are too easy to obtain though. Therefore you'll complete the game quicker?! Surely it should be the other way round. 

I think you have to disregard the terrible UX and Wifi only factors. Yes it's ££ but it's also very Nintendo and meant for kids. 

Please make more Tour Levels, easier to invite friends to play and share progress too!

It can be quite repetitive and boring considering there's not much to the story. Think how many free levels you get with King games!

**SPOILER ALERT**

There's only 20 Kingdom levels?! Cool story bro. 

You can only receive 99 Rally Tickets, 9999 Toads and there's not much to do with the Coins. Seeing as you can't visit your friends Kingdoms yet what's the point in decorating eh?!

The characters should have been harder to unlock. Luigi FTW!

I thought Rainbow bridges or completing Missions might have unlocked more levels but sadly not. 

And eventually you do unlock the Princess' cake at the end. But it doesn't appear to do anything, just sits in the middle of your Kingdom & jumps when you tap it - funny that.  

Sigh.

Anyone who is familiar with Nintendo will know what to expect in terms of quality. It plays brilliantly, and looks great. 
In order to play, you will need to be online, i understand nintendo made it this way to combat piracy, which is fair enough.
As other reviewers have said, a home console version of Mario is going to cost about 30-35 quid and upwards, and although the content doesn't compete with a "proper" Mario game, the quality is definitely there, and you will find yourself returning for toad rally, or to collect all the pink/purple/black coins, unlocking the other playable characters etc. 
If you can spare £7.99 I doubt much people will be disappointed, especially those of you that can tell a quality game over a poor one.
P.s to perform updates just open the App Store and click on updates on the bottom left

data.content:
Things I like about this game: I get to play Mario on my iPad, every level changes slightly when you get various stages (pink coins, purple coins and black coins), the Toad Rally games playing against other people.

Things I don’t like about this game: I do really hate the auto run, and it takes a little getting used to for controlling it. I’ve got used to it but would genuinely prefer a version that does not auto run, because it doesn’t auto run as much as auto strolls. It stalls frequently, there’s a lag in Rally for response - for example, if, when running, you get a star just as you’re about to jump and clear a pipe with a piranha, the lag can make you drop into the piranha and get killed, both ending the star run and killing you to send you back. You can learn to live with this, but I just got a lag that meant I was exited out of the Rally after a win - and when I opened the app again, I found it stole some of the toad people because I exited out of Rally (I didn’t, I was frozen out). 

Generally, this game is fine - but I’ve been playing on the unpaid version trying to decide whether to purchase it or not. So 1) Can’t complain too much about the free version. But 2) I can note the things that are keeping me from purchasing it for the paid version. I enjoy this enough to play it once every couple days, but not enough to be tempted into paying for it.
data.title: Not great, but fine

data.content:
Mario has been a classic for generations, and playing this was fun, however not having an offline mode is stupid, I mean the download itself is huge! So why can't I play it offline? Also the game just crashes with an error code when I'm using 4G, and I can clearly see a strong signal and other online games work fine.

For a company like Nintendo with a reputation for taking pride in their gameplay, they didn't think this one through, it felt slightly rushed and could have had more content for the price. 

Overall I still can't deny I had fun and the one handed gameplay was smartly thought out, I just wish they would have perfected the bugs by now and added more content as 6 levels finished way too fast. So is it worth the price tag? Not really, £4.99 would be more appropriate, but regardless of all the flaws I did enjoy playing it on my wifi & it was still very enjoyable :) #NintendoFanBoy #HonestReview
data.title: Almost amazing, but too many flaws.

data.content:
While it's great to have Mario back, no advertisements, some very good sound effects and music (all of which are the reasons I've given this game 2 stars), the gameplay itself is poor and it doesn't work without an internet connection, which means that I can't play it work or when travelling.

Collecting coins isn't as satisfying as it should be and their placement in the game feels additional. Killing the mushrooms or turtles also feels additional, as if their presence in the game is for nostalgia only.

Nope, the purpose of the game seems to be to collect those special coins, which is often very frustrating rather than fun, especially with the ungenerous timer which defeats the point of having back bubbles. That said, those back bubbles are essential to the game but they're made to feel like a bonus feature.

You're forever having to tap pause and retry and start again from the beginning. This isn't what Mario's about, this isn't fun.

Poor gameplay in my opinion and with so much wasted potential. The £10 price tag is ridiculous.
data.title: Poorly designed

data.content:
Be aware that while this is a free app, it's pretty much a free taster giving you access to the first three levels - if you want the entire game you have to pay £7.99 and that opens up the full 24 levels.

To be be honest, the 24 levels are actually pretty easy... I'd 'completed' the game within about 60 minutes of play. However you can keep going back to collect pink, purple and black coins that unlock rally coupons - something which I don't fully understand the point of at this point in time. Collecting these coins takes longer than the initial completion of the levels!

In summary, this is a great game, a real must for any Mario fan! I'd love to see more levels though. 
The one touch control is really inspired and makes it easy to play anywhere. £7.99 seems (very) pricey for an app, but this is really a console quality game - given the number/ease of levels I'd say the value is just about spot-on. If I could go back in time I wouldn't hesitate to download again!

data.content: Much has been written about the game’s divisive £8 price point – there’s a good summary here – but to me this game has been incredible value for money. It turns out that competing against your friends for coins and Toads is exactly the ingredient that Mario needed all along. I wrote off 2D platformers earlier this year, but Super Mario Run is the game that made me fall in love with them again.

data.content:
This game is designed for people of all skill levels, but if you don't figure out how to be really good at it, the price might seem a bit steep. 

My issues are with some of the gameplay elements Nintendo don't normally mess up (interrupting me mid-jump with 'Coin Rush!' is really irritating, and the ghost runners are incredibly distracting). 

The online thing is a commuter issue, but not a problem anywhere else. 

It's expensive by iOS standards, but very, very cheap by Nintendo standards and well worth it to not have ads or microtransactions etc. 

One of the best-quality games I've played on iOS. Even if it does drive me mad at times!
data.title: High quality, not perfect

data.content:
When you initially play this game, it's one of those games that you just have to continue to play. It's Super Mario after all. But when you finish the 3 free levels of the tour mode, you have to pay £8 for the rest of the TOUR levels. It's a good thing that that's the only amount of money you need to pay to play this game fully and the only purchase you can make.

Positives:
1. This is a good game to play if you have some spare time.
2. Only 1 purchase. No others.
3. Good graphics with good frame rates.
4. Makes the tour modes more challenging with a coin objective.

Negatives:
1. £8 can be a lot of money for most users.
2. Rally mode can only be played by obtaining rally tickets which can be hard to get. Playing the bonus game MAY give you 1 rally ticket. The mystery boxes MAY also give you tickets. Or you can buy them using Nintendo points. Rally mode also lasts a very short amount of time.
3. Tour mode finishes extremely fast despite the coins objective.

I didn't pay the £8 like most people did too but so far it's a GOOD game to play. Although I do see it getting to a point where you don't need to play anymore as you have unlocked and got everything. Only the rally mode will become relevant. If you wish to add me as a friend, my ID is: 5388-2158-8116.

data.content: Any Nintendo head out there will tell you that the Japanese gaming giants have yet to join the 21st century in terms of exclusive titles, not following the pattern of any demand (graphically or otherwise) and insisting on their own unique brand of gaming and control systems. This makes sense as they are the only true gaming company left. However, it may have cost them on occasion and they might have missed a trick appealing to the ageing gamer who has now grown up with a Nintendo that has not evolved with the gaming zeitgeist, but rather on its own tangent. This is great for kids and non gaming adults alike but the middle generation have been somewhat neglected. In all fairness, a mobile version of a classic Mario game is long overdue, and as far as Nintendo keeping all their cards close to their chest, this is one of the holiest! This is not only a great game but could be the start of an era of integration for Nintendo where it's hottest property might be saleable for a price (and £7.99 for a Nintendo product isn't unreasonable) on a format that isn't its own. The militant era could be over!!
data.title: We need more of this forward thinking from Nintendo

data.content:
Everyone else has pointed out the good stuff.

But the need for an excellent internet connection when loading, starting a level, and ending a level make this essentially unplayable for commuters, and people outside of cities, and kids without mobile data not on wifi.
BUT they don't tell you this BEFORE you purchase....

I expect better, frankly. No other app is quite that low.

ALSO when it says "Try again after relocating to Silicon Valley" it is lying: clicking try again even if you are in a bath full of routers will have no effect. Most unenjoyable if you finally complete a level and your connection broke while you were playing.

data.content: Initially the game looks great and the mechanics are smooth. Although I enjoyed playing this game, it has no replay value at all. It's extremely easy and managed to complete all the levels and worlds in around an hour. The rally mode kept me busy for a couple of days but this too becomes very repetitive as there aren't many levels or variations of the worlds. All in all the game is well made and authentic, but it's very short and doesn't offer much. I would recommend this game if it was cheaper, but I feel it's not worth the £7.99 price tag.

data.content:
If I'd have reviewed this game when I first downloaded it and paid the £7.99 soon after, I would have rated 5*
However I am really pleased I waited because now I can give an honest and more balanced view of the game. 
Like many MARIO is a reminder of my childhood and young adult gaming days, I eagerly and impatiently awaited the arrival of the wonderful little plumber. From the time I downloaded him onto my precious iPhone and game device of choice these days, I was hooked! I played for hours, which is not unusual for a Super MARIO Bros game! I quickly completed the first three levels and decided £7.99 was a worthy investment for some nostalgic game play. 
But! And this is the kicker guys....As others have said the game is repetitive, very rapidly completed (no I haven't collected all the purple and black coins but I have most of them) I have however always got a full house of rally tokens (Max is 99) they are easy enough to obtain if you get all the coins from each level and then from reward boxes and game houses in your kingdom. 
I enjoy many a rally against other opponents but have quickly learned that only the flying ship level is worth completing and most of the time I win (which really does get tedious) 
I enjoyed working through these though and collecting toads to progress my kingdom, which again I raced through. To my utter disappointment come level 20 that is it! No more kingdom upgrades available, and therefore no real need to continue with the rally mode as I now have no need for toads except to unlock princes peaches special house, as I've run out of room in my kingdom now it just seems a pointless exercise. 
After doing some research it would seem that even though those big guys in Nintendo took £7.99 from each of us for this promising game, they have failed to deliver. They have no plans to update the game, or add any content. So disappointed doesn't even cover it! 
So to sum up! Not worth £7.99! Not at all!
data.title: Glad I waited!

data.content:
Super Mario is a classic game which I used to love and enjoy, and although this game is OK, it's nothing on the old games.

Firstly, £8 for an app on iOS is too expensive - I'd pay £4.99 tops for the extension package. Toad Rally is fun but you soon run out of Rally Tickets, and with no other means of getting them other than the ? box and if you're lucky on the bonus game, it's nothing but short-lived. 

On top of this, I keep getting an annoying "Try again after finding an area with better connection" notification, despite having full signal or being connected to a strong WiFi point.

This isn't a game I can't wait to play or am constantly on - but if I'm bored, or waiting for my bread to toast, I might play for a few minutes, instead of refreshing Twitter.

3* - Good effort Nintendo, but if you lower the price for the extension package, I think you would find that you'd have a lot more purchases.

data.content:
I downloaded this app on release day. And was immediately disappointed... It didn't take long to complete the first 3 levels to then be hit with the purchase screen demanding £7.99 to unlock all levels... 

I saw all the complaints come rolling in and the pitiful 2 1/2 star rating this game had attracted and though I'd wait it out and just play the Rally and daily mini game thinking Nintendo would realise it is rather expensive and lower the price, even if it was just for the Christmas period however this didn't happen. 

I eventually plucked up the courage to ought over the £7.99. And I must say. What a phenomonal game. I've been hooked since! The game just gets better and better. I have got over 2000 toads now and unlocked 4 islands. I also can't stop getting rally tickets from the '?' Surprise boxes. Of which I now have 4! I have stopped playing after world 3 to trying and give myself a chance to battle the Rally tickets down as I'm permanently on 99! 

Moral of the story and my only advice to anyone readying this and anyone who has played the first 3 levels and enjoyed it, I know it's very expensive. But pay the £7.99. It will give you months of fun, and will be worth it. £7.99 for months of happiness isn't much in the grand scheme of things. Plus it is a one off payment. All future levels will be free as they say 'pay to unlock ALL levels' so would be cheeky to throw in more in app purchases later. 

I hope this review really helps people make up their mind and take the jump. 

What a sensational game!! 😎

data.content:
I love Mario and I was delighted to here there was a 'free' game on the AppStore by Nintendo. Unfortunately it seems as if Nintendo are milking their cash cow brand; Mario. It will drain your wallet and your mobile data! 

 Seeing as the game was in the free section I obviously presuming the game to be funded by either ads or micro transactions, I was wrong.

The game only has the first three levels free. After which you have to pay 8 GBP ( or as they like to call it 7.99 so it seems cheaper) for the additional 21 levels. My question to you is would you pay a quid for 2.65 levels of a fairly short game?

Quite frankly this is a rip off, the worse thing is this game is in the free category, it is a paid game with a demo. I believe this to be part of the marketing ploy as most people will download a game if it's free just to try it and it is Mario, thus pushing the game to higher spots in charts for more views. Hence why it's #1 free download but only 24th in sales.

Also it requires a constant internet connection so goodbye data.
data.title: Don't listen to the Nintendo Fanboys

data.content: A full Super Mario game for £7.99 is nothing to complain about. No annoying in app purchases etc. Great graphics and playability. Super Mario fans will probably sail through the levels but there are the challenges of getting all pink coins, then purple and black. A fun "rally" where you can play against other users and well, can't help loving building the Kingdom and seeing all the toads having a blast.
data.title: Definitely worth it

data.content:
I downloaded this game and played the first few levels and was really enjoying the game. However, after beating the third level, I went into the castle level, of which I could only play 20 seconds of, and after beating the first 20 seconds it presented me with a screen saying I had to pay £7.99 to continue. £7.99!!!! What on earth are Nintendo thinking charging that much money for a few more levels!!! However after complaining a little I did purchase the game, but it took me about 15 mins to complete.

I think that this game also needs a better control system, I didn't expect a control system as awful as this. Mario will automatically run, which is VERY annoying because sometimes you need to go back because you missed one of the pink coins, I understand why Mario automatically runs, but I think that more thought should've gone into this.

The kingdom builder is ok, but I really don't see the point in it. However I do like the idea of it as it gives you something else to do instead of endlessly trying to beat other people in the toad rally mode. 

Toad rally is quite fun, but annoying because of the mechanics. Two complaints I have is why on earth you need the rally tickets. That is something I did not imagine requiring beyond my wildest dreams. Also the coin rush is something that really is not explained very well and really confused me when that first happened.

The last thing I had a problem with is the bowser boss battles. I think because of the mechanics, it's quite hard to create a boss battle that works easy with the game mechanics. It took me at least 4 attempts to clear the bowser castles.

Finally,
I have one thing to say about this game that is good, the graphics. The graphics are way better than I expected for a mobile game. Well done Nintendo! 

I do Think that you should think twice before buying the game though.

• Each level has 6 pink coins, collect them all and then find 6 purple followed by 6 black. Each set is more challenging than the last!

data.content:
I don't usually write reviews, but having played MARIO in the 90's, this game is a great addition to the family of MARIO games. 

Simple to get to grips with, a longer time to master your moves. 

I paid the £7.99 happily to access the full game. Anyone moaning about the price, can stop whinging as it's the price of a few cups of coffee. I recall when games like this cost upwards of £50 back in the day. And it's a one off charge, so I don't think Nintendo are trying to milk it, unlike some other games, with their never ending 'in app purchases'. 

The game is fun. It draws you in, collecting various coins and makes you revisit levels to collect the harder coins as your skill set improves. 

A big thumbs up from me!

data.content: Nintendo have been heavily resistant on releasing their games on non-Nintendo hardware for years and this is one of a few rare occasions in which a Mario game has appeared on one. I like the visuals and simple control scheme, but I consider the length of the World Tour levels to be too short and their design to be too bland. (I wish they were made longer and had more elements.) Also, there are only two power-ups (Super Mushroom and Super Star). If Nintendo updated (or did a sequel) to this app I want to have local and/or online multiplayer, more power-ups and each world to have a specific  theme. Still, this just a start for the Mario iOS series.

I personally love this game. I grew up with Mario and it does feel like the originals. There are flaws, it's a new game, of course there are going to be:

Internet connection, I play this at home of an evening so it doesn't really effect me but if I were commuting on the tube... I would find this irritating. 

I'm hoping an update will bring more levels in the future because 24 levels just isn't enough.

The game itself takes a little getting used to, I'd love to be free to explore the levels and have flower power, but that's just me wanting to experience the best mario game EVER on the SNES. 

Bottom line, I think it's worth the 7.99, no in app purchases (which I hate!).

data.content:
Fantastic game as it has always been and a great re-make of a classic! However, as you can tell by the title this review is not about the game itself. 

Nintendo made the 2 best selling games consoles at the beginning of the gaming era (DS and Wii) at an affordable price of £100 for the wii with 2 remotes, this was new technology to the world. Yet £7.99 for the rest of mario?

This is just an app like any other but because it is a classic game nintendo feel the need to rip people off? 

If this said £7.99 to buy at first instead of just 'GET' and then they pounce on you after 4 levels, it would not be first in the app store.

Nintendo should have followed niantic and done an in-app purchase system and more profit would've been made since it is up to the user and less money-grabbing.
data.title: What happened to Nintendo?

First of all I want to point out that, to those who don't know, the game is free for the first 3 levels, to which you then require to purchase the remainder of the game for £7.99. I want to start out by saying that I have no issue nor should you with paying this sum of money, it may be a mobile game however it functions and feels just as it would say a 3DS console where you would pay £30-£40 for the cartridge. 

The game is full of nostalgia and for someone like me - who isn't THAT MUCH of a Mario lover - I LOVE IT! I can't stop playing it and I certainly haven't completely the main game as I've spent most of my time doing the side quests or other mini games. 

This game is well worth the money and it's a shame that it's damaged nintendos shares the way it has, based on the fact that people don't want to pay!

data.content:
All these negative reviews because of the price are a huge shame as this game is one of the best I've played on my phone/tablet.

Ironically, I bet many people have spent FAR more than £8 on in-game micro transactions in other games without even realising that they're doing it... one payment here and it's Mario Time.

Anyway - this game is surprisingly big. The 24 levels have 3 challenges that get progressively harder, and that's before you even start to go deep into the painfully addictive Toad Rally, a mode where skill is rewarded in order to beat people online.

If your a Nintendo/Mario fan then have no doubts, this is an excellent addition to the series and worth every penny... just be prepared to lose hours of your life.

data.content:
The quest to not just complete Tour mode, but to collect all the pink, then purple, and then black coins, make this a sublime Nintendo experience - imo perhaps the best version of 2d mario we've had in a while. Mastering the constant running mode whilst trying to figure out how to leap, bounce and send shells after those tricky to reach coins, with only a bubble or two to rewind a little, makes this an addictive and unique experience. 

There is also something wonderful about building my little kingdoms (I'm on four at the moment) and seeing the toads play around the items I have placed. 

Always on internet connections aside (not a fan), this is a classic Nintendo experience for touch screen and I'm really pleased at what they have done.
data.title: Pink, Purple, Black

data.content:
It's actually very difficult to collect all 3 coloured coins for the 24 levels and therefore very addictive and worth the £8.00. There is also rally mode where you compete against other people's past runs/game-plays, which is also quite challenging (e.g. to get to 1000+ points).

All of the bad reviews are about the price but I think the game is good value once unlocked.

data.content:
People really don't understand what it takes to develop and fund a game of this caliber. You should be happy it's not a dreaded Freemium game! With all this moaning Nintendo might make future games using the Freemium model. 

Very well designed and highly addictive. If you own an iPhone it is must buy. 

The levels are well designed and Rally is really addictive. 

I can't believe people are complaining about the price. A lot of time, money and effort was put into this game, it is without a doubt worth the £7.99. 

The only issues I have with the game is that it is a little light on levels. There are six worlds, each with four stages (only 24 levels) and it doesn't take long to complete each one. There is some replayability as each level has special coloured coins that you can collect and each different coloured coin is in a different location by even this won't keep you coming back for too long. 

The other thing that could be an issue for some is the game needing an always on internet connection. This hasn't been an issue for me but I could see how it could be a problem for some. 

Overall I think this is a great game and a must buy for any iPhone owner or Mario fan.

data.content: i downloaded this thinking it would be at least an okay mario game. it took about 5 minutes to load, then a further 2 "downloading content." when i finally got to the actual game, it took me through a basic tutorial, then let me play. There are no mechanics except jump, and spin (while in midair,) meaning you have no way of going back to correct mistakes. You don't actually control mario - all you can do is jump. Furthermore, after about 2 minutes i had completed the first set of levels, and clicked on the next one, foolishly hoping i might be able to actually play the game. But no. You can't even play past the first couple of levels without paying, which frankly is awful. This "game" is really not worth your time, let alone money.
